anki_vector.opengl_viewer¶

This module provides a 3D visualizer for Vector’s world state and a 2D camera window.

It uses PyOpenGL, a Python OpenGL 3D graphics library which is available on most platforms. It also depends on the Pillow library for image processing.

The easiest way to make use of this viewer is to create an OpenGLViewer object for a valid robot and call run with a control function injected into it.

Example

import anki_vector
from anki_vector import opengl_viewer
import asyncio

async def my_function(robot):
    await asyncio.sleep(20)
    print("done")

with anki_vector.Robot(show_viewer=True,
                        enable_camera_feed=True,
                        enable_face_detection=True,
                        enable_custom_object_detection=True,
                        enable_nav_map_feed=True) as robot:
    viewer = anki_vector.opengl_viewer.OpenGLViewer(robot=robot)
    viewer.run(my_function)

Warning

This package requires Python to have the PyOpenGL package installed, along with an implementation of GLUT (OpenGL Utility Toolkit).

To install the Python packages do pip install .[3dviewer]

On Windows and Linux you must also install freeglut (macOS / OSX has one preinstalled).

On Linux: sudo apt-get install freeglut3

On Windows: Go to http://freeglut.sourceforge.net/ to get a freeglut.dll file. It’s included in any of the Windows binaries downloads. Place the DLL next to your Python script, or install it somewhere in your PATH to allow any script to use it.”

Classes

OpenGLViewer(robot[, resolution, projector, …]) OpenGL-based 3D Viewer.

Exceptions

VectorException Raised by a failure in the owned Vector thread while the OpenGL viewer is running.
class anki_vector.opengl_viewer.OpenGLViewer(robot, resolution=None, projector=None, camera=None, lights=None, show_viewer_controls=True)¶

OpenGL-based 3D Viewer.

Handles rendering of both a 3D world view and a 2D camera window.

import anki_vector
from anki_vector import opengl_viewer
import asyncio

async def my_function(robot):
    await asyncio.sleep(20)
    print("done")

with anki_vector.Robot(show_viewer=True,
                        enable_camera_feed=True,
                        enable_face_detection=True,
                        enable_custom_object_detection=True,
                        enable_nav_map_feed=True) as robot:
    viewer = anki_vector.opengl_viewer.OpenGLViewer(robot=robot)
    viewer.run(my_function)
Parameters:
  • robot (Robot) – The robot object being used by the OpenGL viewer
  • show_viewer_controls (bool) – Specifies whether to draw controls on the view.
add_render_call(render_function, *args)¶

Allows external functions to be injected into the viewer which will be called at the appropriate time in the rendering pipeline.

Exmaple usage to draw a dot at the world origin:

def my_render_function():
    glBegin(GL_POINTS)
    glVertex3f(0, 0, 0)
    glEnd()

my_opengl_viewer.add_render_call(my_render_function)
Parameters:
  • render_function (<built-in function callable>) – The delegated function to be invoked in the pipeline
  • args – An optional list of arguments to send to the render_function the arguments list must match the parameters accepted by the supplied function.
close()¶

Called from the SDK when the program is complete and it’s time to exit.

run(delegate_function)¶

Turns control of the main thread over to the OpenGL viewer

import anki_vector
from anki_vector import opengl_viewer
import asyncio

async def my_function(robot):
    await asyncio.sleep(20)
    print("done")

with anki_vector.Robot(show_viewer=True,
                        enable_camera_feed=True,
                        enable_face_detection=True,
                        enable_custom_object_detection=True,
                        enable_nav_map_feed=True) as robot:
    viewer = anki_vector.opengl_viewer.OpenGLViewer(robot=robot)
    viewer.run(my_function)
Parameters:delegate_function (<built-in function callable>) – external function to spin up on a seperate thread to allow for sdk code to run while the main thread is owned by the viewer.
